messages.text:
Yeap, we define a function:

```function cassini_oval(agent)
    t = LinRange(0, 2π, 50)
    a = agent.growthprog
    b = 1
    m = @. 2 * sqrt((b^4 - a^4) + a^4 * cos(2 * t)^2) + 2 * a^2 * cos(2 * t)
    C = sqrt.(m / 2)

    x = C .* cos.(t)
    y = C .* sin.(t)

    uv = reverse(sincos(agent.orientation))
    θ = atan(uv[2], uv[1])
    R = [cos(θ) -sin(θ); sin(θ) cos(θ)]

    bacteria = R * permutedims([x y])
    Shape(bacteria[1, :], bacteria[2, :])
end```
and then map it across all agents, which provides a `Vector{Shape}`

messages.text:
I am making a breakout-like game and am using `Makie.jl`  to render and play the game. I have an array of `GeometryBasics.HyperRectangle{2, T}` to be plotted that represent the bricks. The bricks get removed one by one after colliding with the ball. The problem occurs with the last brick, which when removed, throws an error while plotting: `ERROR: LoadError: No meshes to merge`, which makes sense because it is trying to plot `Rect`s from an empty array. I could add a brick at a location that is out of reach for the ball so that the array being plotted is always non-empty. I was wondering if there is a better workaround than this hack.
```...
    bricks_node = Makie.lift(env_node) do env
        bricks = get_bricks(env)
        return map(brick -> get_plotting_shape(PP2D.get_shape(brick), PP2D.get_position(brick)), values(bricks))
    end

    Makie.poly!(scene, bricks_node, color = :lightgreen, linestyle = :solid, strokewidth = 2.0, strokecolor = :black)
...```
The `get_plotting_shape` basically just returns a `GeometryBasics.HyperRectangle{2, T}` object.
```get_plotting_shape(rect::PP2D.StdRect{T}, pos::SA.SVector{2, T}) where {T} = GB.Rect(pos .+ PP2D.get_bottom_left(rect)..., PP2D.get_width(rect), PP2D.get_height(rect))```

messages.text:
The current system just differentiates between `button down` and `button up` so you have to do something like `if ispressed(scene, button) && was_not_pressed` to figure that out. You also can't stop events because Observables just call everything that's connected to them.

Both are things I tried to fix in <https://github.com/JuliaPlots/AbstractPlotting.jl/pull/634>. `events.mousebutton` and `events.keyboardbutton` are little structs there, with press/repeat/release information in  `action` fields. All the events are changed to `PriorityObservables` that are ordered by a `priority::Int8` you can set, and that will stop propagating an event if a listener returns true. Because of that event listeners only work with `on` and should always return a `Bool`.

If you're trying to make a game that pr should be quite helpful, I think. It would also be nice for me if someone tried that pr and told me if anything is broken or weird. I was using it for a couple of weeks without issues, but I also wasn't making a game...

messages.text: Looking at the documentation, specially at <http://makie.juliaplots.org/stable/makielayout/layoutables_examples.html#Layoutables-and-Widgets|Layoutables & Widgets> at first it looks nice, but then afterwards its hard to see how to incorporate the `sliders`, and `toggles` into things in the plot. Let's say show points/or not [toggle], or increase the number of point shown in the plot with the slider. Using Interact, something fast will be to do the following:

elements.text: Looking at the documentation, specially at
Layoutables & Widgets

sliders
, and
toggles
into things in the plot. Let's say show points/or not [toggle], or increase the number of point shown in the plot with the slider. Using Interact, something fast will be to do the following:

messages.text:
```using Interact, GLMakie
@manipulate for i in slider(1:0.01:2, value = 1, label = "move")
    fig = Figure(resolution = (400, 400))
    ax = Axis(fig)
    lines!(ax, 1:10, (1:10).^i)
    fig[1,1] = ax
    limits!(ax, 1,10,1,100)
    fig
end```

elements.text:
using Interact, GLMakie
@manipulate for i in slider(1:0.01:2, value = 1, label = "move")
    fig = Figure(resolution = (400, 400))
    ax = Axis(fig)
    lines!(ax, 1:10, (1:10).^i)
    fig[1,1] = ax
    limits!(ax, 1,10,1,100)
    fig
end
